newsitem.title: FRANCE: French hospital doctors strike enters fifth week.
newsitem.headline: French hospital doctors strike enters fifth week.

text.p: A strike by French junior hospital doctors against government plans to curb health spending entered its fifth week on Tuesday with protesters calling for a 24-hour stoppage of all non-emergency care on Wednesday.
The strikers, dismissing reports that the protest was losing steam, called on the country's other doctors to join them in what they called a "health blackout".
Junior doctors in Lille dumped pig manure in front of the national health insurance fund's offices and painted the building facade red.

The strikers said they were preparing more disruption and planned a march through Paris on Sunday supported by unions representing specialists in private practice who have opposed any reform to France's health system.
But there were signs that support for the strike was eroding as the doctors feel the financial pinch of their long protest.
Unions said the number of teaching hospitals on strike had fallen to 21 from 24 of the 26 in the country. The government put the number at 18.
Press reports said most chief residents, who once supported the movement, had gone back to work.

The government said on Tuesday about 31 percent of the junior doctors in hospitals on strike outside Paris were not working, down from a government estimate of 40 percent last week. The unions put the figure at 70 percent.
They said the return to work by some doctors showed devotion to their patients, not slackening support for the protest.

Both sides have said they want to find a way out of the conflict, but little progress has been made since the weekend when doctors and Social Affairs Minister Jacques Barrot issued calls for negotiations.
The strikers want the government to scrap or delay plans to fine all doctors in a region, regardless of individual practice, if the area overshoots spending limits.
The movement has developed into a test of the conservative government's resolve to cut deficits to allow France to qualify for the European Union's planned single currency in 1999.
While rejecting demands to eliminate or delay the fines and accusing the strikers of selfishly promoting their own interests, Barrot has offered to make the penalties more individualised.
